title: How to Cook Turnips

steps.headline: Choose the freshest turnips.
steps.description: Fresh turnips will feature a heavy skin, be firm to the touch, and have lush green tops. Avoid any turnips with brown spots or have unhealthy looking green tops, as these are sure indicators of older age. The older your turnip, the more bitter it will taste.

steps.headline: Use a sharp knife to cut off the green stalks.
Rinse the turnips in cool water.
steps.description: This will remove any bacteria or dirt.

steps.headline: Peel the turnips.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife to peel the tough skin away from the turnips. If the turnip is already peeling or the skin is cracked, then you will need to peel the older layers away to expose the newer, fresher surface underneath. This is similar to the method for peeling an onion.

steps.headline: Heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil in a skillet over medium low heat.
steps.description: Wait 30 seconds or so for the butter to heat up.

steps.headline: Sauté 1 cup of chopped onion in the skillet.
Slice 3-4 turnips into thin strips.
steps.description: Cut them into thin strips that resemble french fries.

steps.headline: Add the turnips to the skillet with the onion once it begins to soften.
steps.description: Add another tablespoon of olive oil to the skillet.

steps.headline: Cook the turnips for 5 minutes and then reduce the heat to low.
steps.description: Continue cooking them until they're tender. Then, remove them from the heat and season them with salt and pepper to taste.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: Sprinkle the turnips with 1 tbsp. of lemon juice, toss them to combine them with the vegetable, and serve them while they're hot.

steps.headline: Light a grill.
Quarter 1 pound of turnips.
steps.description: When you're done, run them through a toothpick to make the grilling process easier.

steps.headline: Brush the turnips on both sides with 1 tbsp.
steps.description: of olive oil.

steps.headline: Season them with salt and pepper to taste.
Grill the turnips over moderately high heat until they're tender.
steps.description: It should take about two minutes to grill each side of the turnips. When you're done, move them to a platter.

steps.headline: Cook 1 tablespoon of garlic and 2 tablespoon of olive oil over high heat in a skillet.
steps.description: Wait 1-2 minutes until the oil is sizzling.

steps.headline: Reduce the heat to low.
steps.description: Cook the garlic for about 2 more minutes or until it's golden.

steps.headline: Turn off the heat and stir in 2 tablespoon of chopped parsley and 1 tsp.
steps.description: of pepper. Mix the ingredients until they're thoroughly combined.

steps.headline: Spoon the oil mixture over the turnips.
Serve.
steps.description: Top the turnips with the zest of 1 lemon and enjoy them while they're hot.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 500ºF (260ºC).
steps.description: Put the track in middle position.

steps.headline: Peel and quarter 1 1/2 lbs.
steps.description: of turnips. The pieces should resemble lemon slices.

steps.headline: Melt 1 tablespoon of unsalted butter in a small skillet.
Toss the turnips with the melted butter in a small bowl.
steps.description: Season them with salt and pepper to taste.

steps.headline: Place the turnips onto a roasting pan.
steps.description: Make sure to leave room between the pieces.

steps.headline: Roast the turnips for 25-30 minutes, until they're tender and brown.
steps.description: During the process, you should toss and shake the pan once or twice to make sure that the turnips are evenly roasted.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: Enjoy these tasty roasted turnips while they're hot.

steps.headline: Substitute half of the potatoes in your usual favorite potato recipe with turnips.
steps.description: Prepare the turnips in the same manner you would the potatoes. The result will be a subtle, surprising flavor.

steps.headline: Slice the turnips and serve them raw.
steps.description: These slices can then be eaten alone with a dash of salt, or you can use them on hamburgers or other dishes in place of raw onions.

steps.headline: Grate the raw turnips.
steps.description: Use a cheese grater to grate them. Place them on top of your favorite salad. They'll add a crunchy texture and a bright flavor.

steps.headline: Mince the turnips and add them to soups.
steps.description: Place then into your favorite soups just before you cook them, just as you would with celery or onion pieces.They will simmer in the broth and add a rich flavor.

steps.headline: Blanch the turnips.
steps.description: Cut the turnips into thick slices, and blanch them in a steamer for 3 to 5 minutes. Place them atop a cookie sheet, and put them in an oven at 130ºF/54ºC for approximately 8 to 10 hours. Once they feel dry or brittle to your touch, remove them and let cool. Serve them dried as a snack, or add them to soup such as you would crackers.

steps.headline: Finished.
